prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our science goal we need to determine whether the disk is large (R$\geq$250 AU) or significantly smaller. A disk of R=250 AU at a minimal distance of 100 pc corresponds to an angular size of 3'' on the sky. To constrain the size of a small disk of an order of magnitude smaller (R=25 AU) at a distance of 150 pc, an angular resolution of 0.33'' is required. Therefore band 6 is selected for our science goal. If the flat disks in our sample are large (~250 AU) than we need the sensitivities so that we can observe the disks out to 250 AU. We estimate the required sensitivities using model fits to the 1.3mm flux for all targets. We adopt the surface density and temperature from our model to calculate the expected flux/beam from the outer disk. For a total disk dust mass of M_dust=3*10^-4 M_sun, the model has at R~250 AU a surface density of ~0.003 cm^2 g^-1 and an outer disk temperature of T~20 K. We estimate the expected flux/beam using F_nu = surfdensity * beam_size * B_nu(T=15K) * mass_opacity, where B_nu is the Planck function and beam_size the beam size in sr. We adopt a mass opacity 2.3 cm^2 g^-1, which includes a gas-to-dust ratio of 100. Finally, the required sensitivity needed to detect the large flat disks at a 3 sigma level is F_nu/3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The nature of self-shadowed proto-planetary disks surrounding intermediate mass pre-main-sequence Herbig Ae/Be stars is a remarkable mystery. We propose to observe a representative sample whose outer disk structure has been elusive until now. Almost all observational tracers of the disk structure in these ``flat'' disks are dominated by the inner $\sim$10 AU. Therefore we do not know their outer disks, which may be possibly geometrically small or highly settled and flat. ALMA is the first and only instrument with the sensitivity and spatial resolution needed to measure the size of the outer disk. These observations allow an unambiguous test of the relation between observed spectral energy distribution and outer disk evolution by grain growth, planet formation and radial drift.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek, University of Amsterdam
SRON Utrecht, SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research
Department of Astronomy, Chile, University of
